title: 112_hr2527
content: The "National Baseball Hall of Fame Commemorative Coin Act" recognizes the historical significance of the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum, which opened in 1939 in Cooperstown, New York. The Hall of Fame honors legendary players like Ty Cobb, Babe Ruth, and Honus Wagner, setting a high standard for induction. Only one percent of Major League Baseball players have been inducted since its establishment. The museum aims to preserve history, honor excellence, and connect generations through the rich history of baseball, which reflects the nation's heritage. The National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum, established in 1939 in Cooperstown, New York, houses the world's largest collection of baseball artifacts, documents, photographs, and recorded media. It serves as an educational institution, attracting millions of visitors annually to learn about the history of baseball and its connection to American heritage. The National Baseball Hall of Fame Museum offers interactive educational programs using baseball to teach students various subjects. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint $5 gold coins in honor of the Hall of Fame. The coins minted under this Act shall weigh 8.359 grams, have a diameter of 0.850 inches, and contain 90 percent gold and 10 percent alloy. Additionally, $1 silver coins shall weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper. Half-dollar clad coins shall weigh 11.34 grams, have a diameter of 1.205 inches, and be minted to specific specifications. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The coins minted under this Act will be considered numismatic items. Congress suggests that $1 and $5 coins should be designed similarly to the 2009 International Year of Astronomy coins. The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the National Baseball Hall of Fame and the Commission of Fine Arts. The coins minted under this Act will have a value designation, the year "2014" inscribed, and include words like "Liberty", "In God We Trust", "United States of America", and "E Pluribus Unum". The Secretary will hold a competition to determine the design of the common obverse of the coins, emblematic of baseball, with proposals submitted according to the approval process developed by the Secretary. The Secretary will hold a competition for the design of the common obverse of the coins, with proposals accepted from artists, engravers, and the public. Compensation for the winning design will be at least $5,000. The reverse design of the coins will depict a baseball. The Act specifies the issuance and sale of coins by Major League Baseball. Coins will be minted in uncirculated and proof qualities and can only be issued during a 1-year period starting on January 1, 2014. The sale price includes the face value, a surcharge, and the cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted. The Secretary will accept prepaid orders for coins minted under the Act before issuance, with sale prices at a reasonable discount. All coin sales will include surcharges of $35 for the $5 coin, $10 for the $1 coin, and $5 for the half-dollar coin. Surcharges will be paid to the National Baseball Hall of Fame to support its operations. The National Baseball Hall of Fame is subject to audit requirements. No surcharge can be included if it exceeds the annual commemorative coin program issuance limitation. The Secretary will ensure that minting and issuing coins will not result in financial issues. SEC. 9. BUDGET COMPLIANCE. The Act ensures that minting and issuing coins will not incur costs to the US Government. No funds are disbursed until all costs are recovered by the Treasury. Budgetary effects will comply with the Statutory Pay-As-You-Go Act of 2010. The Chairman of the Committee on the Budget of the House of Representatives must submit a statement before the vote on passage.
